In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) stems from the need for developing countries to 
improve public sector management (PSM) so that they can better manage their economies and 
deliver public services more efficiently and effectively. The TA is anchored on two core concepts 
that affect the quality of development work of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Asia and 
the Pacific: (i) good governance, including effective PSM, and (ii) knowledge generation and 
dissemination in PSM, and partnership with institutions as part of ADB’s commitment to drivers 
of change in Strategy 2020.1 
 
2.  With  respect  to  enhancing  knowledge  generation  and  dissemination  in  PSM,  a 
partnership with the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy (LKYSPP) in Singapore is proposed. 
Two fact-finding missions to Singapore (in September 2010 and May 2011) were undertaken to 
finalize the project design. The LKYSPP has concurred with the impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  costs,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The 
design and monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  There are three issues with respect to the application of good governance 
 
A.  Why Focus on Governance and PSM? 
4.  Good  governance—a  concept  that  encompasses  effective  PSM—is  a  quintessential 
public good needed for market stability and economic development benefiting all people on a 
nonrival  basis.  The  benefits  of  good  governance—and  by  implication  the  costs  of  poor 
governance—also accrue to all others interacting with a particular jurisdiction. Governance, thus, 
has important regional and global dimensions. This necessitates a deep understanding of the 
overarching political economy and governance system in which PSM operates.  
 
B.  How to Better Generate and Disseminate Knowledge in PSM 
5.  One of the challenges of development is how to access and share knowledge in all 
spheres of development activity, particularly on governance, public policy, and PSM. Many good 
practices in these areas have not been documented or disseminated widely and effectively, thus 
limiting the scope of learned lessons to better inform public policy and PSM across Asia and the 
Pacific. Engaging in collaborative research as a way of enhancing and disseminating knowledge 
is an important way to reduce the knowledge gap on PSM in the region. This, coupled with high-
profile events (such as international forums, executive education, and training), will also help in 
projecting PSM to the forefront of the development agenda in the region.  
 
C.  How External Partnerships Can Benefit ADB 
6.  The primary issue to be addressed in knowledge generation and dissemination in areas 
associated with PSM is how external partnerships with relevant institutions can be developed so 
as  to  enable  ADB  to  best  fulfill  its  mandate.  ADB’s  Strategy  2020  encourages  external 
                                                 
 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
  Manila. http://www.adb.org/strategy2020/ 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website in 17 August 2011.

2  
knowledge partnerships and serves as an important context for the TA.3 Strengthening such 
partnerships enables ADB to fulfill one of its major roles as a multilateral development bank—to 
promote learning and innovation to the benefit of developing member countries. Deepening 
research  in  priority  areas  of  Strategy  2020  is  an  outcome  indicator  of  ADB’s  Knowledge 
Management Action Plan. Strategy 2020 also stresses the need to strengthen public sector 
capacity  and  management  practices  in  priority  sector  areas  that  include  infrastructure, 
environment, regional cooperation initiatives, finance, and education.  
 
7.  What  is  needed  is  a  synergy  between  practice  and  analytics  to  generate  applied 
knowledge on PSM that can be shared regionally. Practice-based knowledge merits wider 
dissemination in a form that is useful to governments, state-owned enterprises, and others to 
help inform public policies. Such knowledge products developed and disseminated through a 
reputable knowledge platform can enhance the outreach and impact of these products. 
 
D.  Value-Added Proposition of the Partnership with the Lee Kuan Yew School of 
Public Policy (LKYSPP) 
8.  To better address these issues, the TA will enable ADB to draw upon the expertise and 
breadth of reach of a premier academic institution and think tank in Asia—the LKYSPP in 
Singapore.4 The knowledge outputs generated from a partnership with the LKYSPP will not only 
position ADB at the core of knowledge sharing on PSM in Asia and the Pacific but will also 
inform and frame the public management debate in the region.  
 
9.  Pursuant to the memorandum of understanding reached between ADB and the LKYSPP 
in October 2009 for this type of knowledge management collaboration,5 it is proposed that ADB 
establish  a  primary  partnership  with  the  LKYSPP  given  the  very  close  alignment  with  its 
objective (of raising the standards of governance throughout the region and improving the lives 
of the region’s people) with that of ADB (poverty reduction in Asia and the Pacific).6 The 
partnership, however, can be expanded, where relevant, to other noted institutions (footnote 5). 
Partnering with the LKYSPP on PSM-related areas will help showcase ADB as a proactive 
knowledge institution by putting ideas into practice and by emphasizing applied research to 
better inform PSM ideas. This will directly help ADB regional departments in their work. 
 
                                                 
 
3  In July 2009, ADB’s President approved a plan to advance the knowledge management agenda under Strategy 
2020. Organized into four pillars, the plan is designed to (i) sharpen knowledge focus in ADB operations, (ii) 
empower communities of practice, (iii) strengthen external knowledge partnerships, and (iv) further enhance staff 
learning and skills development.  
4  While the primary focus of the proposed TA is on the partnership with the LKYSPP, the TA will explore 
opportunities and options to expand and enrich this partnership by including other noted and relevant institutions 
and research think tanks, such as the Asian Development Bank Institute, through participation in the proposed 
public sector management conference (output 2). Similar partnerships with ADB are in the pipeline for other 
reputed institutions in Asia, including Seoul National University. 
5  In addition, there has been a rich inventory of professional activities already undertaken in partnership between the 
LKYSPP and ADB on issues related to water governance and urban water management, climate change, and 
improving aid effectiveness. 
6 In 2009, LKYSPP was ranked 7th among 40 top Asian think-tanks, and is the only institution in the top ten that is 
dedicated to work on PSM and public policy. All the others are in areas of international affairs, social sciences, 
economic research, and strategic studies. This is drawn from the ranking of The Think Tanks and Civil Societies 
Program of the University of Pennsylvania in 2009 (see The Straits Times. 2010. “Four S’pore think-tanks among 
Asia’s top 30”. January 31). The criteria for ranking include academic reputation, success in generating innovative 
policy ideas, and access to elites in the areas of policymaking, media, and academia. As is clear, on public policy 
and PSM, LKYSPP is the most credible institution in Asia, hence its appeal for purposes of this project.

3
10.  The relationship with the LKYSPP will be valuable to ADB as: (i) the LKYSPP offers ADB 
the opportunity to reach out extensively to high-level officials in countries in Asia who are its 
alumni (the school trains nearly 2,000 public officials every year in key areas of financial reforms, 
public management reform, urban planning, and public–private partnerships); (ii) the School’s 
faculty has scholars and practitioners from all over the world who can help bridge ideas in 
research to the practical application of knowledge in development undertakings, particularly in 
Asia, and many have had professional experience with the World Bank, International Monetary 
Fund, Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, and ADB; (iii) the School’s 
four  well-regarded  specialized  research  institutions  will  allow  ADB  to  draw  on  specialized 
expertise;7 and (iv) the School has also networked extensively with other reputable institutions 
of higher learning and research in Asia and around the world.8 ADB can tap into the knowledge 
base of these partnerships, thus considerably expanding its outreach. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be reflected in better-informed PSM policies, programs, and practitioners 
in the developing member countries of Asia and the Pacific. This is expected to result from 
inspired  leadership,  managed  transformation,  and  leveraged  learning  opportunities.  The 
outcome will be knowledge generation and dissemination of good practice in public policy and 
PSM related to ADB operations. The focus of the TA outcome will be on the sustenance of a 
long-term relationship between ADB and the LKYSPP which enables the LKYSPP to continue, 
and to catalyze, knowledge generation and dissemination in public policy in PSM-related areas, 
including partnering with other reputable knowledge institutions. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The area of coverage will be region-wide since all ADB’s developing member countries 
can potentially benefit from the ADB–LKYSPP partnership. Specific TA outputs will include the 
following: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Research products in public policy and PSM. Basing the research 
agenda on both operational and policy-focused research, these products will 
include practice-based research reports, policy briefs, and assessments so as to 
inform the policy debate on areas of operations that ADB’s regional departments 
are involved in. The research products (while country specific) will be placed in 
the regional context based primarily on the political economy, and drawn from 
across a variety of sectors covering ADB’s priority areas of focus. ADB will 
prioritize topics related to (a) public financial management; (b) public–private 
partnerships, especially municipal finance for infrastructure; (c) PSM at sector 
level; and (d) decentralization.9 The research methodology will include literature 
                                                 
 
7 These institutions are (i) the Asia Competitiveness Institute, which studies ways to boost the region’s productivity; 
(ii) Centre on Asia and Globalization, which examines the impact of globalization on Asia and Asia’s role in global 
governance; (iii) Institute of Policy Studies, which focuses on Singapore’s own policies; and (iv) Institute of Water 
Policy, which looks at comparative management, conservation, and use of water. 
8  Including University of Tokyo, Tsinghua University (Beijing), London School of Economics, and Harvard University. 
9 The topics that have been specified build upon the work that ADB has already done in these areas and keeping in 
view the work as suggested by the regional departments. In particular, research topics that have been confirmed 
are (i) public roles of the private sector (public–private partnerships) in India, (ii) innovations in subnational 
financing mechanisms and tools, (iii) designing an equitable and sustainable framework for natural resource

4  
reviews, field visit studies (where relevant), surveys, and comparative studies.10 
ADB  staff  from  regional  departments  and  the  Governance  and  Public 
Management Community of Practice (CoP) will participate in the broad research 
agenda through reviews to ensure practice-based research. 
(ii)  Output 2: Public policy and PSM conference and associated forums and 
workshops. The conference and associated forums and workshops will focus on 
ensuring that knowledge dissemination also takes place through face-to-face 
interaction such that researchers as well as practitioners from across the region 
can share and analyze knowledge gained under output 1. The conference topics, 
to be finalized later in consultation with the LKYSPP, but in ADB’s areas of 
priority,  will  include  (a)  overall  PSM  in  developing  member  countries  in  the 
macroeconomic  context,  (b)  subnational  finance  and  decentralization  as  it 
impacts economic growth and delivery of essential public services, and (c) public 
financial management as a fundamental challenge to public sector and sector 
governance reforms. 
(iii)  Output 3: Training for developing member country officials on policies of 
subnational financing. The LKYSPP’s comparative advantage of being one of 
the region’s leaders in executive education—as well as existent expertise in 
financing, public–private partnerships, etc.—will be used to impart practice-based 
training to developing member country officials in public policy of subnational 
financing, including (a) strengthening the intergovernmental fiscal transfer system, 
(b) evaluating options for municipal financing such as through local bond markets, 
and (c) enhancing the role of the private sector in resource pooling, e.g., for 
infrastructure financing. 
 
13.  There  are  no  risks  in  the  TA  related  to  social  and  environmental  concerns,  public 
financial management, procurement, or corruption. Other risks related to the TA are detailed in 
the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1) but one that merits mention is the lack of 
practical application of the research products and conference. The TA design has incorporated 
relevant risk mitigation measures through ADB staff reviews to account for this risk. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) for $500,000. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the proposed TA. Project administration will be 
managed by the team leaders with active assistance from a project coordinator (an individual 
national  consultant  funded  by  the  TA  and  contracted  for  9  person-months  [PMs]  on  an 
intermittent basis). A project steering committee representing the CoP at ADB (comprising the

Republic of China, (v) impact of micro finance on poverty in Pakistan, and (vi) Indonesia’s fiscal decentralization 
and devolution of land and property taxes. There is some flexibility in accommodating additional topics to capitalize 
on upcoming topical developments for which regional departments require analytical work. 
10  The specific nature of the appropriate research methodology will vary by subject area. However, given the fact that 
ADB has considerable knowledge of the practice of public management and its various domains, the knowledge 
gap in policy and analytical implications is expected to be filled by researchers at the LKYSPP.

5
two  co-chairs)  and  the  vice-dean  (academic  affairs)  at  the  LKYSPP  will  provide  strategic 
guidance.11 The steering committee will meet bi-annually, or as needed. The TA duration will be 
from October 2011 to October 2013.  
 
16.  The LKYSPP will provide the venue for the proposed PSM conference, help frame topics 
and issues of the conference in collaboration with the Governance and Public Management CoP, 
and contribute research papers that will document empirical, conceptual, and practical issues 
across a wide range of public management concerns relevant for developing Asia. The LKYSPP 
will also provide inputs for the conference website to be established at ADB. Peer review of the 
research papers and the conference proceedings will be done by individual experts selected by 
ADB. Sector experts drawn from regional departments and the CoP will provide quality control 
by reviewing the research products and by providing inputs relevant to their sectors (especially 
with respect to the operational aspects of the research papers). 
 
17.  While  there  will  be  one  letter  of  agreement  with  the  LKYSPP  for  purposes  of  this 
partnership, for the delivery of outputs there will be two specific contracts, both time-based and 
by single-source selection.12 The LKYSPP will be responsible for three specific outputs: (i) 
developing and piloting a subnational financing module through its Executive Education unit; (ii) 
producing research outputs in specific subject areas (see footnote 9); and (iii) organizing the 
PSM conference which builds on the research work. The first contract (for $100,000) will be for 
the training, and the second (for $200,000) will be in equal amounts for the research and the 
conference. In addition to the TA project coordinator, an international individual advisor and 
Singapore-based event managers13 for the PSM conference will also be contracted under the 
TA for 1 PM and 6 PMs respectively. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Their 
terms of reference are in Appendix 3. Disbursement under the TA will be made in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
18.  Good practices and lessons from the TA will be disseminated through (i) the PSM 
conference, which will showcase substantive research products; (ii) the regular publication of 
research products in top internationally refereed journals; (iii) the LKYSPP and ADB websites; 
and (iv) incorporation of TA products in LKYSPP training and course modules. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Collaborative  Research  and  Advisory  Services  on  Public  Sector  Management,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
 
11 The justification for placing the proposed TA within the ambit of the Governance and Public Management CoP is 
that knowledge generation and dissemination cuts across regional departments, and also that it incorporates the 
diversity of expertise that individual members of the CoP currently possess. 
12 It is proposed that the LKYSPP be selected on a single-source basis given the nature of services to be provided, 
and given its substantive credibility on development research in Asia. It also has prior association with ADB which 
accords it a comparative advantage over other research institutions (para. 10). 
13 The event managers are proposed to be from Singapore so that country-specific knowledge will enable transaction 
costs of organizing the conference to be lower for the TA. See Appendix 3 for detailed terms of reference.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A total of 16 person-months of national and international consulting services will be 
required to ensure that the technical assistance (TA) is effectively managed and the outcome 
achieved. 
 
A.  Project Coordinator (national (Manila-based), 9 person-months, individual, intermittent)  
 
2.  The project coordinator will have a postgraduate degree in any of the social sciences, 
such as economics, public policy, or public and international affairs. He or she will have had 
more  than  5  years  of  prior  experience  in  managing  TA  projects;  experience  with  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) projects is an advantage. He or she will be selected on an individual 
basis as per the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time) and will report to the project officers. 
 
3.  The responsibilities of the project coordinator are to 
(i)  ensure  the  proper  implementation  of  the  TA,  including  ensuring  the  TA 
deliverables of other consultant(s); 
(ii)  liaise with the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy (LKYSPP), as needed, to 
ensure that work on the TA is proceeding smoothly; 
(iii)  manage the contracting process within ADB, including working with the Central 
Operations  Services  Office  and  Controller’s  Office  to  expedite  project 
administration; 
(iv)  collate  all  required  reports,  and  forward  them  to  relevant  departments  and 
divisions within ADB and elsewhere for prompt review and feedback;  
(v)  develop a website for the partnership, with help from the Office of Information 
Systems and Technology, and update it regularly in partnership with the LKYSPP;  
(vi)  work with the event management firm and with relevant developing member 
country officials (through ADB resident missions, where necessary) to ensure 
participation in training and the public sector management (PSM) conference at 
the LKYSPP; 
(vii)  carry  out  tasks  and  coordinate  with  the  event  management  firm  and  the 
international advisor to ensure that work on the conference will be a success 
(e.g.,  act  as  liaison  between  the  LKYSPP  and  ADB  resident  missions  for 
information sharing on the events); 
(viii)  liaise  with  ADB’s  Department  of  External  Relations  (DER),  as  needed,  for 
purposes of facilitating production of the conference proceedings by the LKYSPP; 
and 
(ix)  carry  out  other  tasks  (including  with  the  event  management  firm,  and 
international advisor) as needed to ensure that the TA meets its outcome. 
 
4.  The project coordinator will be responsible for the following outputs: project management, 
website  management  on  the  partnership,  support  to  the  PSM  conference,  production  of 
conference proceedings, and reporting for the TA. 
 
B.  Advisor (international, 1 person-month, individual, intermittent)  
 
5.  The international advisor will have a suitable and high-level academic and professional 
background in public sector management, international political economy, and business studies. 
He or she will also have more than 5 years’ demonstrated experience in designing or helping 
design major development-oriented events and conferences. Prior experience working with ADB

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
events is an advantage. He or she will be selected on an individual basis, according to the ADB 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and will report to 
the project officers. 
 
6.  The advisor will: 
(i)  contribute significantly to the design of the PSM conference, in collaboration with 
the LKYSPP but working through the ADB project team; 
(ii)  liaise with ADB on the conference content and delivery mode; 
(iii)  help  peer  review  all  conference  presentations,  and  provide  summaries,  as 
needed, to ensure smooth conference implementation; 
(iv)  guide  the  project  coordinator  and  the  event  management  firm  in  aspects  of 
conference implementation and by acting as a facilitator, where needed; and 
(v)  prepare, as needed, any research notes/papers on aspects of the conference. 
 
7.  The advisor will be responsible for the following outputs: support for PSM conference 
design and delivery, peer review of conference contents, and conference facilitation. 
 
C.  Event Managers (national (Singapore-based), 6 person-months in total – detailed 
below, individual) 
8.  There will be three individuals supporting event management (for the PSM conference), 
that will be recruited from a Singapore-based firm (this is so as to minimize transaction costs of 
supporting an event within Singapore). The individuals will have had prior experience supporting 
events  such  as  the  conference.  Demonstrated  experience  in  working  in  development  and 
academic settings is preferable. The firm will be selected using the least-cost selection method 
with the contract on a lump sum basis. Recruitment of the firm will be done according to the 
ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).   
 
9.  The  event  managers  will  ensure  the  smooth  conduct  of  the  conference,  including 
working  with  the  LKYSPP  on  organizational  arrangements,  logistics,  documentation,  and 
outreach. The terms of reference of the three individuals are as follows: 
 
(i)  Conference organizer (4 person-months, intermittent): 
 
(a) participate in, and document, internal pre-conference meetings;  
(b) draft and send invitation letters to internal and external participants, respond to 
inquiries, and liaise with international and regional experts, speakers, and ADB 
resident missions (if needed) to confirm attendance; 
(c) coordinate all logistical arrangements for the conference, including arrangements 
for  hotel  accommodation,  visas,  travel  of  participants,  consultants,  resource 
persons,  food  services,  cocktail  catering,  invitations,  provision  of  multimedia 
devices, workshop banners, identifications for participants, and others; 
(d) liaise with ADB’s DER, as needed, through the project coordinator, to ensure the 
event is duly covered by international media services, including through the ADB 
Media Center, and within ADB (ADB Today and ADB website announcements); 
(e) facilitate protocols for the event; 
(f)  provide  and  coordinate  secretariat  support  during  and  after  the  conference, 
including disbursement of per diem to participants and liquidation of expenses; 
(g) provide support on all activities related to a successful hosting of the conference;

Appendix 3  13 
 
(h) take guidance from the international advisor on the design of the conference. 
 
(ii) Communication specialist (1 month, intermittent): The specialist will ensure the 
effective communication of the messages of the conference to participants and will 
design creative ways of communicating these to prospective sponsors of future events. 
The tasks, in this regard, will include the following: 
 
(a) analyze the communication needs of the PSM conference; 
(b) devise the most effective means of conveying the information to the participants 
and the wider public audience that would enable the conference to create interest 
at senior level of developing member country governments (this includes drafting 
the conference prospectus); 
(c) together with the LKYSPP and DER, design and implement a communication 
plan for disseminating the information to the public through print and other media, 
including  guidelines  on  the  timely  and  effective  implementation  of  the 
communication plan; 
(d) assist  in  creating  and  helping  maintain  the  specific  website  and  other 
communication needs and related tasks. 
 
(iii) Editor  (1  month):  The  Editor  will  be  in  charge  of  the  conference  proceedings 
production and editing. He/she will also be involved in: 
 
(a) preparing a master list and compiling all final print and electronic versions of 
conference reports, speeches, presentations, and handouts; 
(b) handle copy editing of all materials related to the conference and other pertinent 
materials; and 
(c) liaising with DER in assisting the uploading of the post-conference statement and 
ensure that conference materials are web-ready. 
 
D.  LKYSPP staff (exact number of person-months cannot be specified given that 
their involvement is continuous during the entire TA) 
 
10.  Even though the staff members of LKYSPP involved in this TA are not consultants per 
se, it is still considered useful to briefly highlight their roles and responsibilities for the three 
components of the TA. These roles and responsibilities of these staff members, and others that 
may be involved during TA implementation, will be included in any agreement between ADB 
and LKYSPP. The terms of reference of the LKY staff members for the three components of the 
TA will be as follows: 
 
I.  For the research component 
 
(i)  Determine  scope  of  research  for  the  specific  research  topic  in  collaboration  with 
relevant ADB staff member(s); 
(ii) Develop  specific  research  methodology  in  collaboration  with  relevant  ADB  staff 
member(s); 
(iii) Carry out research including conducting field visits, as required; 
(iv) Work with ADB to present interim conclusions and findings in workshops, symposiums, 
etc., so as to enable peer review of research results; 
(v) Prepare papers on research results, and present them, at the PSM conference;
